newsitem.title: UK: BAA doesn't expect to be hit by windfall tax.
newsitem.headline: BAA doesn't expect to be hit by windfall tax.

text.p: British airport operator BAA Plc said on Thursday that it has made it clear to the UK Treasury that it does not expect to be included in the government's windfall tax.

The company said in a statement that it was taking legal advice on the issue of the windfall tax, which the British government plans to impose on what it calls the "excess profits" of privatised utilities.

BAA said that like British Telecommunications Plc it had suffered from media speculation about the windfall tax. The new Labour government has so far declined to identify the companies it plans to targets.
"Like BT, we are not a utility, not a monopoly, and have not had excess profits," the company said.
"We have been frustrated by the refusal to count us in or count us out. This has for months surrounded the company with uncertainties and inevitably affected shareholder confidence," said BAA.

The company said that it has been looking forward to working with Labour in developing an integrated transport strategy but, "frankly, the way we have been allowed to be included in speculation about the tax is unfair and verges on irresponsibility".
